medical: PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Dorsal ganglion, right wrist. POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Dorsal ganglion, right wrist. OPERATIONS PERFORMED: Excision dorsal ganglion, right wrist. ANESTHESIA: Monitored anesthesia care with regional anesthesia applied by surgeon. TOURNIQUET TIME: minutes. DESCRIPTION OF PROCEDURE: With the patient under adequate anesthesia, the upper extremity was prepped and draped in a sterile manner. The arm was exsanguinated and the tourniquet was elevated to 290 mm/Hg. A transverse incision was made over the dorsal ganglion. Using blunt dissection the dorsal ulnar sensory nerve branches and radial sensory nerve branches were dissected and retracted out of the operative field. The extensor retinaculum was then incised and the extensor tendon was dissected and retracted out of the operative field. The ganglion was then further dissected to its origin from the dorsal distal scapholunate interosseus ligament and excised in toto. Care was taken to protect ligament integrity. Reactive synovium was then removed using soft tissue rongeur technique. The wound was then infiltrated with 0.25% Marcaine. The tendons were allowed to resume their normal anatomical position. The skin was closed with 3-0 Prolene subcuticular stitch. Sterile dressings were applied. The tourniquet was deflated. The patient was awakened from anesthesia and returned to the recovery room in satisfactory condition having tolerated the procedure well.
layman:
PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Dorsal ganglion on the right wrist.  
POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Dorsal ganglion on the right wrist.  

OPERATIONS PERFORMED: Removal of the dorsal ganglion on the right wrist.  

ANESTHESIA: The patient was given monitored anesthesia care with a regional block applied by the surgeon.  

TOURNIQUET TIME: minutes.  

DESCRIPTION OF PROCEDURE:  
The patient was fully anesthetized. The arm was cleaned and covered with sterile drapes. Blood was removed from the arm and a tourniquet was set to 290 mm/Hg. A horizontal cut was made over the ganglion. The surgeon gently separated the sensory nerves from the ulnar and radial sides and moved them out of the way. The outer layer of the wrist (extensor retinaculum) was cut, and the extensor tendon was moved out of the field. The ganglion was carefully freed from the ligament that connects the scaphoid and lunate bones and then removed completely. The surgeon made sure the ligament stayed intact. Any inflamed lining (synovium) was removed with a small tool. The wound was given a local anesthetic (0.25% Marcaine). The tendons were put back in their normal positions. The skin was closed with a 3â€‘0 Prolene stitch. Sterile dressings were applied. The tourniquet was released. The patient woke up from anesthesia and went to recovery in good condition, tolerating the surgery well.
